result_equations.equation: vec L = vec r xx vec p
vec tau = vec r xx vec F

explanation: Angular momentum is the rotational analog of linear momentum, quantifying the rotational motion of a particle or system about a reference point. Defined as the cross product of position and momentum vectors, it is an axial vector whose direction indicates the rotation axis. The time derivative of angular momentum equals the torque, leading to the conservation law: angular momentum is conserved when no external torque acts on the system. This principle governs phenomena from planetary orbits to spinning tops and is fundamental to both classical and quantum mechanics.

definitions.definition: Angular momentum vector about the reference point, with units `kg cdot m^2 / s`.
Position vector from the reference point (origin) to the particle.
Linear momentum vector, `vec p = m * vec v`.
Torque vector (moment of force) about the reference point, with units `N cdot m`.
Force vector acting on the particle.
Net external torque acting on the system.
Cross product (vector product) of two vectors.

derivation.description: Define angular momentum as the cross product of the position vector `vec r` and linear momentum `vec p`. This definition captures the rotational content of motion about the origin.
derivation.equation: vec L = vec r xx vec p

derivation.description: Express momentum in terms of mass and velocity to obtain the equivalent form.
derivation.equation: vec L = vec r xx (m * vec v) = m * (vec r xx vec v)

derivation.description: To find how angular momentum changes in time, compute its time derivative using the product rule for cross products.
derivation.equation: (d vec L)/(dt) = (d)/(dt) (vec r xx vec p) = (d vec r)/(dt) xx vec p + vec r xx (d vec p)/(dt)

derivation.description: The first term involves `(d vec r)/(dt) = vec v`. Since `vec p = m * vec v`, this becomes `vec v xx (m * vec v)`.
derivation.equation: (d vec r)/(dt) xx vec p = vec v xx (m * vec v)

derivation.description: The cross product of any vector with itself (or a parallel vector) vanishes. Since `vec v` and `m * vec v` are parallel, their cross product is zero.
derivation.equation: vec v xx (m * vec v) = m * (vec v xx vec v) = 0

derivation.description: Apply Newton's second law: the rate of change of momentum equals the net force.
Substitute into the time derivative of angular momentum. The first term vanishes, leaving only the second term.
derivation.equation: (d vec L)/(dt) = 0 + vec r xx vec F

derivation.description: Define torque (moment of force) as the cross product of position and force vectors.
derivation.equation: vec tau = vec r xx vec F

derivation.description: The rotational analog of Newton's second law: torque equals the rate of change of angular momentum.
When no external torque acts on the system (`vec tau_(ext) = 0`), angular momentum is conserved. This is the rotational analog of conservation of linear momentum.
derivation.equation: vec tau_(ext) = 0 => (d vec L)/(dt) = 0 => vec L = text{constant}

code: # Steps 1-2: Angular momentum definition L = r x p
# Position components as functions of time
r_vec = x * N.i + y * N.j + z * N.k
# Step 1-2: Angular momentum L = r x p
# Steps 3-5: Time derivative of angular momentum
# Step 3: Compute dL/dt using product rule
# d/dt(r x p) = (dr/dt) x p + r x (dp/dt)
# First term: v x p = v x (m*v) = m*(v x v) = 0
# v x v = 0 for any vector (cross product with itself)
# Steps 6-9: Torque and Newton's second law
# Force F = m * a (Newton's second law)
# Step 7-8: Second term gives torque: r x F
# Step 9: dL/dt = r x F = tau
# For circular motion in xy-plane: verify L is constant when tau = 0
# Use r(t) = R*(cos(omega*t), sin(omega*t), 0) for constant R, omega
R, omega = sp.symbols('R omega', positive=True, real=True)
r_circ = x_circ * N.i + y_circ * N.j + z_circ * N.k
# For uniform circular motion, L should be constant (z-component only)
# L = m * R^2 * omega in the z-direction
# Simplify using trig identity cos^2 + sin^2 = 1
# Verify dL/dt = 0 for uniform circular motion (no torque)
# Verify anti-commutativity: a x b = -(b x a)
a1, a2, a3 = sp.symbols('a1 a2 a3', real=True)
b1, b2, b3 = sp.symbols('b1 b2 b3', real=True)
a_test = a1 * N.i + a2 * N.j + a3 * N.k
b_test = b1 * N.i + b2 * N.j + b3 * N.k

historical_context.importance: Fundamental conservation law governing rotational dynamics; essential for celestial mechanics, rigid body motion, and quantum mechanics
key_insights: Angular momentum provides a rotational analog to linear momentum
Conservation of angular momentum explains phenomena from planetary orbits to figure skating spins
The torque-angular momentum relation is the rotational form of Newton's second law
Angular momentum conservation arises from rotational symmetry via Noether's theorem

references.citation: Goldstein, H., Poole, C., & Safko, J. (2002). *Classical Mechanics* (3rd ed.). Addison Wesley.
Landau, L. D., & Lifshitz, E. M. (1976). *Mechanics* (3rd ed.). Butterworth-Heinemann.
